title: Although Somers does not refer either to biopolitics or to Arendt’s approach to narrative, her emphasis on social being, action and ‘intersubjective webs of relationality

618) resonate with certain aspects of Arendt’s ontology of natality. The two important differences are, first, that for Somers behaviour and action are synonymous and, second, arendt, natality and biopolitics social identity explains action and agency, while for Arendt it is action that discloses agency and uniqueness (Somers 1994: 612–15). Somers’s argument about the importance of ontological narrative in sociology is a striking example of W
Mitchell’s claim that stories provide useful methodo­logical approaches ‘for all the branches of human and natural science
